article:
'A-DNA' is one of the many possible double helical structures of DNA. A-DNA is
thought to be one of three biologically active double helical structures along
with B-DNA and Z-DNA. It is a right-handed double helix fairly similar to the
more common and well-known B-DNA form, but with a shorter more compact helical
structure. It appears likely that it occurs only in dehydrated samples of DNA,
such as those used in crystallographic experiments, and possibly is also assumed
by DNA-RNA hybrid helices and by regions of double-stranded RNA.
headings: Comparison Geometries of the Most Common DNA Forms
